item.title: List in list
item.description: Horizontal-list in vertical-list # A worksheet ItemConf in HelloWorld.xlsx: ID Name Prop1ID Prop1Value Prop2ID Prop2Value [Item]uint32 string [Prop]int32 int64 int32 int64 Item’s ID Item’s name Prop1’s ID Prop1’s value Prop2’s ID Prop2’s value 1 Apple 1 10 2 20 2 Orange 3 30 3 Banana Generated: hello_world.

item.title: Map in map
item.description: Horizontal-map in vertical-map # A worksheet ItemConf in HelloWorld.xlsx: ID Name Prop1ID Prop1Value Prop2ID Prop2Value map<uint32, Item> string map<int32, Prop> int64 int32 int64 Item’s ID Item’s name Prop1’s ID Prop1’s value Prop2’s ID Prop2’s value 1 Apple 1 10 2 20 2 Orange 3 30 3 Banana Generated:

item.title: Infinite nesting
item.description: Overview # Now, the horizontal/vertical list element’s first field can be any type, even as struct, list, and map. List element’s first field is struct: [Reward]{Icon}int32 List element’s first field is predefined struct: [Cost]{.Item}uint32 List element’s first field is in-cell struct: [Magic]{int32 Id, int32 Num}Ability List element’s first field is list: [Reward][Item]uint32 List element’s first field is list with element as predefined struct: [Power][.Item]uint32 List element’s first field is map: [Superpower]map<uint32, Ability> TODO: some clear examples.
